title: Cryptomultiplier
author: Cryptomultiplier
content: So the nation Kenya has thought it wise for sometime now to infuse 'coding' as a subject in its basic primary, secondary schools curriculum. It is in a bid to facilitate development in the nation as technology and innovation recounts majorly as the future of mankind. Since 2022 this initiative started, it has shown remarkable improvement in the thinking, team relationship and problem solving skills of these kids in general. Coming down to our country, which is supposedly the giant of Africa, I am yet to see such huge idea incorporated in the primary, secondary schools mostly as unemployment and cost of living is in wake.  No doubt technology is advancing rapidly and the major one, is that of Blockchain, cryptocurrencies and Web3. Other than the government looking for how to tax crypto currency and prevent the youths or unemployed from seeking opportunities therein for their betterment, such an idea of teaching the younger kids in schools should be the priority to grow wealth in the nation within coming years. We need our economy improved and subjects that bother on entrepreneurship, Blockchain, coding, cryptocurrencies, Web3 should be made a common denominator in all schools curriculum. The incoming administration should endeavour to take a cue from the country Kenya and start introducing wealth related subjects like coding, Blockchain, Web3 into all schools curriculum, so as to reduce the hardship and poverty standard of its citizenry in the nearest future. This is how the leaders of tomorrow should become.Any thoughts?For more read about how Kenya has done this, visit the link:https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&source=web&rct=j&url=https://www.africanews.com/amp/2023/04/26/coding-classes-for-children-in-nairobis-kibera-district/

This is how the leaders of tomorrow should become.Any thoughts?The suggestion given above is a very good initiative if implemented by the new President of the Federal Republic of Nigeria "Bola Ahmed Tinubu", because one thing I have noticed about us is that implementation of  laws is never a problem oh, but application of those laws to the fullest is where the problem always lies, and the reason why I think the last administration ended up with many failed projects. But if only our the new governments can review the school curriculum, add new trends such as "Blockchain, Crypto, A.I & Tech", fund it and supervise it to the fullest, then it will be a welcome development to our future leaders of tomorrow.

comments.author: Mate2237
comments.body: Technology is something we can't rush into. Though Nigeria would have been the first country to explore technology but the leaders are busy with looting the public funds. Ajekuta Steel Company in Kogi would been one the best company in Africa to produce iron in the continent but the national leaders just abandoned the project. In the recent days I have discovered that primary school teachers are using internet devices to teach our children. A small pamphlet look like device that has all the subjects. That is the full curriculum is installed in the device. So in the nearest future things might be okay in that aspect of life.

comments.author: Zanab247
comments.body: I believe dis new government have something good for d youths that will make the youths of Nigeria more prosper than Kenya youths, because some of the things the president Bola Ahmed Tinubu promised Naija people during his swearing in last month, he has started doing those things by removing subsidy first, which is our major challenge that is causing corruption in our nation. And the new president promised the youths of Nigeria during his campaign that he will make Blockchain, BTC, cryptocurrencies and other digital business available for the youths to have access to them easily in the country. I don't have any negative doubt for this new administration because our president Bola Ahmed Tinubu is a someone that value the progress of our nation which he will surely do what will make others countries to see Nigeria as the true giant of African.
